node.title: Tests fail when adding some files to ADDITIONAL_APP_OBJECTS in the Makefile
node.bodyText:
Dear moose community,
I am running into an issue when trying to couple an external framework to moose. The additional files are added in the Makefile via
# object files
ADDITIONAL_APP_OBJECTS += $(patsubst %.cpp, %.$(obj-suffix), $(additional_srcfiles))

# dependencies 
ADDITIONAL_APP_DEPS += $(patsubst %.cpp, %.$(obj-suffix).d, $(additional_srcfiles))

But after running make, the test fails with the following output.
(moose) me@cluster:~/Projects/chamois$ ./run_tests 
<frozen importlib._bootstrap>:228: RuntimeWarning: compiletime version 3.8 of module 'hit' does not match runtime version 3.9
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: Working Directory: /local/home/schmithi/Projects/chamois/test/tests/kernels/simple_diffusion
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: Running command: /local/home/schmithi/Projects/chamois/chamois-opt -i simple_diffusion.i --no-gdb-backtrace
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: 
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: Framework Information:
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: MOOSE Version:           git commit 4aee48977f on 2021-10-30
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: LibMesh Version:         
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: PETSc Version:           3.15.1
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: SLEPc Version:           3.15.1
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: Current Time:            Sat Oct 30 14:57:38 2021

test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: Parallelism:
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test:   Num Processors:          1

test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: 
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: Mesh: 
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test:   Parallel Type:           replicated
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test:   Mesh Dimension:          2
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test:   Spatial Dimension:       2

test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: double free or corruption (!prev)
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: Aborted
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: 
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: 
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: Exit Code: 134
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: ################################################################################
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: Tester failed, reason: CRASH
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test: 
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test ............................................................ FAILED (CRASH)


Final Test Results:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
test:kernels/simple_diffusion.test ............................................................ FAILED (CRASH)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 tests in 0.2 seconds. Average test time 0.1 seconds, maximum test time 0.1 seconds.
0 passed, 0 skipped, 0 pending, 1 FAILED

I am not too experienced with building more complex projects. Other input files lead to a similar result. They almost complete and lead to this double free or corruption (!prev) error somewhere after the solver converges. I have not been able to track down the problem with the debugger since the stack is corrupted.
It seems weird to me that the simple diffusion test fails even though it should not depend on the third-party library. Is there some moose function that is overloaded in some unintended way?
I would appreciate any help toward resolving this issue.

Hello
Can you please build in debug mode and get us a backtrace in a debugger?
instructions are here: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html#!
Guillaume
I was able to resolve the issue. My apologies, it had nothing to do with moose directly.

node.title: Piecewise constant material assignment given elemental centroid
node.bodyText:
Hi
I am trying to define the spatial distribution of material given the centroid of each element. The way I am thinking of is that, given the coordinate of the centroid of each element (x,y,z), and the value of the material at this point, each QP in this element will copy that value.
I have tried to use the PiecewiseMulticonstant to achieve this, but obviously, it does some interpolation that I do not want.
For example, in the following picture, this is the output of a simple domain with 2-elements (in 2D). I wanted to assign a value of 1 for the first element, and 2 for the second element. But the results show that element one has a value of 1 and element 2 has a value of 1.5.

The part of the input file associated with this output is as below:

[Mesh]
type = GeneratedMesh
dim = 2
xmin = 0
xmax = 1
ymin = 0
ymax = 1.0
nx = 2
ny = 1
[]


[material_distribution_function]
type = PiecewiseMulticonstant
data_file = material_distribution.data
direction = 'left right'
[]

where the data_file is as follows:

AXIS X
0.25 0.75
AXIS Y
0.5
DATA
1.00
2.00

Any hint regarding this?

Hmm, I didn't think PiecewiseMulticonstant does any interpolation at all, so this is weird.
You are telling the function to read from the left for the x values, so if you replace your AXIS X data with 0 0.5 it should work as you expect.

I dont see how to get rid of the direction. For elemental fields, the centroid of each element is compared to coordinates specified in data_file. We have to decide whether we get the value on the right or on the left.

I wrote that example that you linked to. Looking at it again, it might be useful to replace PiecewiseMultilinear with PiecewiseMulticonstant in the example as it is really setting a constant property in each material.
What you are suggesting with a function that sets a value based on element centroid seems like a specialisation of PiecewiseMulticonstant that would be better as a separate function.
oh are you talking about using some sort of nearest point/neighbor scheme to determine the value?

oh are you talking about using some sort of nearest point/neighbor scheme to determine the value?

Yes, so for example, a user provides the centroid of the element and the value. Then, within each element, instead of comparing the centroid to the coordinates of the mesh as you mentioned, we can compare it to the centroids provided by users. So, in this case, no need to specify the directions. This is just a suggestion, I am not aware of other moose's concerns that may arise /be there.
Then you would provide a value for every element? Or interpolate in between.

Then you would provide a value for every element? Or interpolate in between.

For the PiecewiseMulticonstant I would provide value for each element if it is one-to-one mapping, Yes. And, if it is not one-to-one, or when mesh refinement is needed, we can always compare the centroids of the finite elements with the centroids provided by the users as well.

Ok i ll look into this.
I think someone had started implementing this, with values coming from CSV as well

ok so ElementPropertyFileReader already does all we would want, but:

it's in tensor mechanics
it's a UO rather than a function
I ll make a PR soon to move it to the framework & add a function

ok so ElementPropertyFileReader already does all we would want, but:

it's in tensor mechanics
it's a UO rather than a function
I ll make a PR soon to move it to the framework & add a function


That would be great, thank you.

node.title: LibMesh Update
node.bodyText:
A new libMesh has made its way to the MOOSE master branch. For those using the conda packages, please perform
conda update --all

in your MOOSE conda environment. For those using the the libMesh submodule, please run in the moose/scripts directory
./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh

after updating your copy of MOOSE.
More details on the content of this update can be found in the October 2021 Newsletter.

node.title: October 2021 Newsletter
node.bodyText:
The October 2021 MOOSE Newsletter has been released! A summary of the content is below:

moosetools Repository Removed
Support Ended for PETSc < 3.5
New Reactor Module
New Functor System
3D Mortar Contraints
libMesh Update Summary

node.title: Make a sincere request for help about conda
node.bodyText: x86_64-conda-linux-gnu-c++: fatal error: Killed signal terminated program cc1plus

Hello
Can you please post more context
Guillaume
Please  wait  a  moment  .  It  is  morning  now  and  I  have  a  class  .  I  will  reply  you  later,   ok?
Please help  me!!
Are you running this in a virtual machine? And if so, what resources do you have allocated to it?

I installed  the  Ubuntu  system  in  the  virtual  machine  , and  then  ran  it  in  the  terminal  according  to  the  official  website  instructions.  Finally,  this  error  occurred  in  the  test.
What resources did you give the virtual machine (memory/cpus/storage)?
4Gb
4GB ram or storage

4GB  ram
20GB   storage

I found  a good rule of thumb to be to have at most one concurrent compile process per GB of available RAM. Meaning you should run make -j 4 on your VM. The killed compiler is 99% certainly an out of memory issue.
Run  the  conmand  again?
did you run with a -j argument the first time?
yes
try running just make then. It ll use less resources
first   time   run   with    make  -j   4
Do you have swap set up? Either way try make -j 2
cant see the screenshot

still cant see it
Can you please post it from github rather than email it?
Can you  see  it?   And   it   successful?

looks successful to me!
It compiled and it passed the test for your application.
Does it pass the tests in moose/test?
Most  of  them  are  ok,  but  a  few  of  them  have  been  skipped,  no  mistakes.
You're all set then. Good luck with your modeling!
thanks
Hello, I have a new question to ask you, the first example I run is normal, but as shown in the picture below, the fourth and other examples all report the same error, why is this?

hey @ZJYZXH and @amosaha. Please refrain from posting in Chinese here. While I can read this simple exchange of contact details, most of the community cannot so it's a little uncomfortable for the next person who will consult this post looking for help on the same topic.
I‘m so sorry, and I have deleted the messages.I won’t send such messages.Thank you for reminding me of this rule.
Hey no worries we literally just added it to the guidelines this morning! The situation had not come up before. Good luck with using MOOSE!

This is the first time to do this, and my English is poor, I feel very sorry.
…
---Original---
From: "Guillaume ***@***.***>
Date: Mon, Nov 1, 2021 23:40 PM
To: ***@***.***>;
Cc: ***@***.******@***.***>;
Subject: Re: [idaholab/moose] Make a sincere request for help about conda(Discussion #19216)





Hey no worries we literally just added it to the guidelines this morning! The situation had not come up before. Good luck with using MOOSE!

node.title: Automatic Different for Hydro-mechanical simulation
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose experts,
I plan to use moose to implement the basic hydro-mechanical simulation.
I haven't tried to use Automatic differentiation for porous flow before. The equations I want to implement is straightforward.

Here, \omega is darcy's velocity.
After I finish the implementation using AD, I can't get the converged result.
 0 Nonlinear |R| = 9.839972e-02 Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_NANORINF iterations 0 Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINEAR_SOLVE iterations 0 Solve Did NOT Converge! Aborting as solve did not converge
I want to ask if we can use AD in porous flow problem? I am currently using PJFNK solver. Is it appropriate for this simulation? Thank you!

Hello
If you are using AD you can use Newton instead of PJFNK since the Jacobian you're creating should be exact. This is also the recommended option for porous flow.
But that might not be the issue.
This very first nonlinear residual, is it the same as with a non-AD implementation? It should.
Is it possible to only solve one of the two equations, keeping all other terms constant, for this application? To verify the correctness of the kernels
Did you look at this porous flow documentation https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/tutorial_02.html
has information on numerical solves
Guillaume

Thank you! Since I plan to include some new constituive laws which are pretty complicated, I want to use AD to compute the jacobian automatically. And this simple equation will be my starting point to include more complicated stuff.
I can solve the two equations seperately. But when I add the residual term of (_strain[_qp].trace() - _strain_old[_qp].trace())/_dt*_test[_i][_qp]; for the second equations. The result doesn't converge. So, to deal with porous flow problem, we should implement the jacobian exactly, right? I tried the methods in tutorial but it doesn't work here. Now, the running issues become
`Time Step 1, time = 0.1, dt = 0.1
Performing automatic scaling calculation
0 Nonlinear |R| = 6.380534e+00
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_BREAKDOWN iterations 30
1 Nonlinear |R| = 5.892391e+00
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_BREAKDOWN iterations 30
2 Nonlinear |R| = 5.361072e+00
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 300
3 Nonlinear |R| = 4.711670e+00
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 300
4 Nonlinear |R| = 4.711670e+00
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 300
5 Nonlinear |R| = 4.711670e+00
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 300
6 Nonlinear |R| = 4.711670e+00
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 300
7 Nonlinear |R| = 4.711670e+00
Linear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_ITS iterations 300
Nonlinear solve did not converge due to DIVERGED_LINE_SEARCH iterations 7
Solve Did NOT Converge!
Aborting as solve did not converge`

There's something special about implementing time derivative kernels. If you do it like this you wont be able to leverage all the cool time steppers we have. You have to use the dot functions like the Time Kernels. Unfortunately I m not sure where good documentation for doing this is. @lindsayad do you know?
What is _strain? To check if this type has a dot() function
Maybe have a look at the AD Time Derivative kernel, https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/kernels/ADTimeDerivative.C
which inherits from the TimeKernel, which defines u_dot https://github.com/idaholab/moose/blob/next/framework/src/kernels/ADTimeKernel.C
Other page of interest:
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/executioners/Transient.html

The first thing I would do is compile in dbg mode, like METHOD=dbg make -j8 and then run with the dbg executable and see if you have any floating point exceptions or things like that. I suspect that you do given the errors out of your linear solver.
More documentation on debugging is here
Thank you. I tried both methods you mentioned. I guess the main issue is that the permeability I choose is too low.  To solve this kind of problem, it is better to use explicit jacobian expression.

I'm not an expert on porous flow so I cant comment on that. As a general rule though, AD will give you a better Jacobian than explicit.
@WilkAndy may know what s going on

I'm not an expert on porous flow so I cant comment on that. As a general rule though, AD will give you a better Jacobian than explicit. @WilkAndy may know what s going on

Thank you. Yeah, I can get the code to run right now for a large permeability I choose. Note that permeability is used in darcy's law
$$\vec\omega = \frac{\kappa}{\mu}\nabla p$$
However, I can't get the converged result if kappa is small.
I solve these equations routinely with AD, it for sure works. I second @lindsayad 's suggestion -- it's likely you have a floating point exception somewhere, probably in your constitutive model.

From the above discussion, it is difficult to know whether you're using the PorousFlow module, or your own code.  If you're using the PorousFlow module (and i recommend you do, because this is a simple scenario for PorousFlow) then this physics should be easily modelled using PorousFlowFullySaturated.  Please also read the tutorial pages.  You probably should never use automatic differentiation in PorousFlow models, since all the Jacobian entries are already coded, and you should almost always use solve_type = Newton (i don't think any of the PorousFlow tests or examples use anything else, because in more complicated PorousFlow situations, other nonlinear solvers take too long to converge).

From the above discussion, it is difficult to know whether you're using the PorousFlow module, or your own code. If you're using the PorousFlow module (and i recommend you do, because this is a simple scenario for PorousFlow) then this physics should be easily modelled using PorousFlowFullySaturated. Please also read the tutorial pages. You probably should never use automatic differentiation in PorousFlow models, since all the Jacobian entries are already coded, and you should almost always use solve_type = Newton (i don't think any of the PorousFlow tests or examples use anything else, because in more complicated PorousFlow situations, other nonlinear solvers take too long to converge).

Hi Wilk, I am using my own code. ThePorousFlow module has explicit jacobian and I used it before. Now, I am considering to implement double porosity coupled with plasticity in Moose. But the jacobian is expected to be complex. So, I consider to use AD to compute the jacobian automatically and accurately. I try to use AD to solve the equations above since I want to use it as my starting point for some really complex equations and test if AD could be used for porous flow problem.
Aha, i get it.   Sounds fun!   Probably you need some sort of scaling on your Variables.  Even if you aren't using PorousFlow, this page might be useful to you.

Aha, i get it. Sounds fun! Probably you need some sort of scaling on your Variables. Even if you aren't using PorousFlow, this page might be useful to you.

Thank you for the sharing!

You probably should never use automatic differentiation in PorousFlow models

@WilkAndy, it looks like AD can give a better Jacobian than explicit as @GiudGiud wrote. Why does PorousFlow module not?
If a developer can take the time and write out an exact hand Jacobian, the simulation will run roughly 1.5 times faster

@WilkAndy @lindsayad Thank you for the reply. I get to understand the situation. Before seeing this discussion, I just read the recent paper "Lindsay, Alexander, et al. "Automatic Differentiation in MetaPhysicL and Its Applications in MOOSE." Nuclear Technology (2021): 1-18" and think AD is so attractive for "the guarantee of an exact Jacobian at a relatively small overhead cost".
Anther open-source code MRST (MATLAB based, desktop only) for reservoir modeling seems beneficial in speed from the usage AD.

node.title: MOOSE users at UK universities?
node.bodyText:
First, apologies if it isn't appropriate to ask this question in the discussion forum, and questions should be restricted only to technical matters about MOOSE.
I and colleagues at UKAEA would be interested to know of any researchers or groups currently using MOOSE at UK universities.  If there are any, it would be good to make contact to discuss possible collaboration and maybe support for PhDs.
If you'd like to get in touch, please reply to this post in the forum or send me a direct message.

Dear @EdSheltonUKAEA
Here is one who just landed in the UK:
https://research-information.bris.ac.uk/en/persons/nicol%C3%B2-grilli
Best Regards,
Nicolò Grilli

Dear @EdSheltonUKAEA
Sorry I have not been in touch,
I don't know how to message you directly here and could not find your email online.
If you have still interest in co-supervision of PhD students, especially for the next call of CDT studentships,
you can contact me to discuss at:
nicolo.grilli@bristol.ac.uk
Best Regards,
Nicolò

@EdSheltonUKAEA this question is appropriate in the forum
@friedmud do you know anyone else in the UK using MOOSE?
I don't, unfortunately.

node.title: The First Question about GBAnisotropy
node.bodyText:
Dear MOOSE experts,
Recently, I recently read the input file and C++ file about the anisotropy of grain boundary energy and grain boundary mobility. For test1.i and op_num = 3, I found that only the three GB mobility prefactor in anisotropy_mobility.txt are used by reading GBAnisotropy.C and GBAnisotropyBase.C, as shown in the Fig.1.

And the output of L (the mobility of the order parameter) after the simultion of test1.i is as follow in Fig.2,

Finially, my questions for test1.i are,

The correspondence between $GBmob0_{01}, GBmob0_{02}$ , mobility prefactor of the two grain boundaries (gr0-gr1 and gr0-gr2), and the value in anisotropy_mobility.txt is shown in fig.1, but I don't know if my understanding is correct?
For grain gr1, the intra-grain mobility prefactor is different from the inter-grain boundary perfactor, but the intra-grain mobility prefactor is the same as the the inter-grain boundary perfactor for grain gr1. And I don't know what setting casuse this difference.

Any suggestions or recommendations to fix the problem would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you
Wei
@laagesen @SudiptaBiswas @amjokisaari

Wei, I ran this example and output the parameter L to the exodus file by adding outputs = exodus in the CuGrGranisotropic block. The values of L are a bit different from what is in your schematic drawing.

What you see is that there is a consistent value of L being used in the gr0-gr1 interface (L is consistent between through that interface). Similarly, there is a consistent (larger) value of L being used in the gr0-gr2 interface. These different values give different interface motion for the two types of interface. (There is a third value of L being used, far away from the interfaces and shown in green, but this values doesn't affect microstructural evolution because the order parameters are 1 there).

Thank you so much, @laagesen.

There is a third value of L being used, far away from the interfaces and shown in green, but this values doesn't affect microstructural evolution because the order parameters are 1 there

Yeah, I fully understand what you mean.
Then, what I want to ask is whether the corresponding relationship in Figure 1 is correct, especially for the parameter (1,2),

And, if I set (1, 2) to 5.0e-6, an opposite result will appear, as shown in the figure below, which is very interesting.

Yes I believe what you sketched in Fig. 1 is correct. However I believe if you want to change the gr1-g2 interface mobility, you also need to change the corresponding value of the gr2-gr1 parameter. Think of this as a symmetric matrix, with symmetry about the diagonal. For the values you gave in Fig. 1, it is a symmetric matrix. However when you change gr1-gr2 without changing gr2-gr1, the matrix is no longer symmetric.

ok, thank you so much. I got it.
Now, if I want to extend this Tricrystal simulation to polycrystal simulation without using graintracker object (e.g. op_num = 5, grain_num = 5), GB mobility is a 5*5 matrix in anisotropy_mobility.txt, right?
my results for this polycrystal simulation and GB mobility in anisotropy_mobility.txt are as follow,


Moreover, if I use the graintracker object to reduce the number of the order parameters in this polycrystal simultion (e.g. op_num = 4, grain_num = 5), how do I set my anisotropy_mobility.txt file to get the same result as above?

You're correct about it being a 5 x 5 matrix for 5 grains, and the matrix structure you show in the figure is correct. For the 5-grain simulation, I don't think you're going to be able to reduce the number of order parameters less than 5 because the grains are not far enough apart to avoid them contacting each other. Even if you could, the additional overhead of the graintracker would probably not be worth decreased cost obtained by dropping down one order parameter. GrainTracker is meant for much larger simulations, like if you wanted to simulate 100 grains with 8-9 order parameters.

Yeah， I know it.
I just give an example, although it is not perfect. When I use the graintracker object (e.g. 100 grains and 8 op_num), is this GB mobility matrix is 8 x 8 or 100 x 100 in anisotropy_mobility.txt ? In other words, is the information assigned to the order parameters or to each grain unique_grains in *.txt?
This GB mobility matrix would be 8 x 8, the information is assigned to the order parameters rather than the unique_grains.

Ok, I already understand. Thank you very much for your careful answers.
Wei

node.title: How to save initial stress
node.bodyText:
Hi,
How can I save initial stress? Here is my input file:
[Mesh]
  type = GeneratedMesh
  dim = 3
  nx = 5
  ny = 5
  nz = 5
  xmin = 0
  xmax = 1
  ymin = 0
  ymax = 1
  zmin = 0
  zmax = 1
[]

[Variables]
  [./disp_x]
  [../]
  [./disp_y]
  [../]
  [./disp_z]
  [../]
[]

[Kernels]
  [./TensorMechanics]
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    eigenstrain_names = 'initial_stress'
  [../]
[]


[BCs]
  # back = zmin
  # front = zmax
  # bottom = ymin
  # top = ymax
  # left = xmin
  # right = xmax
  [./xmin_xzero]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'left'
    value = '0'
  [../]
  [./ymin_yzero]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'bottom'
    value = '0'
  [../]
  [./zmin_zzero]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'back'
    value = '0'
  [../]
  [x1]
    type = Pressure
    variable = disp_x
    boundary = 'right'
    component = 0
    factor = 300000
  []
  [y1]
    type = Pressure
    variable = disp_y
    boundary = 'top'
    component = 1
    factor = 200000
  []

  [./zmax_disp]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_z
    boundary = 'front'
    function = '-1E-3*t'  # 8mm
  [../]
[]

[AuxVariables]
  [./stress_xx]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./stress_xy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./stress_xz]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./stress_yy]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./stress_yz]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./stress_zz]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./mc_int]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
  [./yield_fcn]
    order = CONSTANT
    family = MONOMIAL
  [../]
[]

[AuxKernels]
  [./stress_xx]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    variable = stress_xx
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 0
  [../]
  [./stress_xy]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    variable = stress_xy
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 1
  [../]
  [./stress_xz]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    variable = stress_xz
    index_i = 0
    index_j = 2
  [../]
  [./stress_yy]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    variable = stress_yy
    index_i = 1
    index_j = 1
  [../]
  [./stress_yz]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    variable = stress_yz
    index_i = 1
    index_j = 2
  [../]
  [./stress_zz]
    type = RankTwoAux
    rank_two_tensor = stress
    variable = stress_zz
    index_i = 2
    index_j = 2
  [../]
  [./mc_int_auxk]
    type = MaterialStdVectorAux
    index = 0
    property = plastic_internal_parameter
    variable = mc_int
  [../]
  [./yield_fcn_auxk]
    type = MaterialStdVectorAux
    index = 0
    property = plastic_yield_function
    variable = yield_fcn
  [../]
[]

[Postprocessors]
  [./s_xx]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0 0 1'
    variable = stress_xx
  [../]
  [./s_xy]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0 0 1'
    variable = stress_xy
  [../]
  [./s_xz]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0 0 1'
    variable = stress_xz
  [../]
  [./s_yy]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0 0 1'
    variable = stress_yy
  [../]
  [./s_yz]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0 0 1'
    variable = stress_yz
  [../]
  [./s_zz]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0 0 1'
    variable = stress_zz
  [../]
  [./mc_int]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0 0 1'
    variable = mc_int
  [../]
  [./f]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0 0 1'
    variable = yield_fcn
  [../]
  [./uzz]
    type = PointValue
    point = '0 0 1'
    variable = disp_z
  [../]
[]

[UserObjects]
  [./mc_coh]
    type = TensorMechanicsHardeningConstant
    value = 70E3
  [../]
  [./mc_phi]
    type = TensorMechanicsHardeningConstant
    value_0 = 0.52  # 30 degree
  [../]
  [./mc_psi]
    type = TensorMechanicsHardeningConstant
    value = 0
  [../]
  [./mc]
    type = TensorMechanicsPlasticMohrCoulomb
    cohesion = mc_coh
    friction_angle = mc_phi
    dilation_angle = mc_psi
    mc_tip_smoother = 0
    mc_edge_smoother = 25
    yield_function_tolerance = 1E-3
    internal_constraint_tolerance = 1E-10
  [../]
[]

[Materials]
  [./elasticity_tensor]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    block = 0
    poissons_ratio = 0.3
    youngs_modulus = 207e6
  [../]
  [./strain]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrain
    block = 0
    displacements = 'disp_x disp_y disp_z'
    eigenstrain_names = 'initial_stress'
  [../]

 [initial_strain]
   type = ComputeEigenstrainFromInitialStress
   initial_stress = '-3e5 0 0  0 -2e5 0  0 0 -1e5'
   eigenstrain_name = initial_stress
   use_displaced_mesh = false
 []


  [./mc]
    type = ComputeMultiPlasticityStress
    block = 0
    ep_plastic_tolerance = 1E-10
    plastic_models = mc
    max_NR_iterations = 1000
    #debug_fspb = crash
  [../]
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [./andy]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  [../]
[]


[Executioner]
  end_time = 0.8
  dt = 0.05
  solve_type = PJFNK  # cannot use NEWTON because we are using ComputeFiniteStrain, and hence the Jacobian contributions will not be correct, even though ComputeMultiPlasticityStress will compute the correct consistent tangent operator for small strains
  type = Transient

  line_search = 'none'
  nl_rel_tol = 1E-10
  l_tol = 1E-3
  l_max_its = 200
  nl_max_its = 10

  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_asm_overlap -sub_pc_type -ksp_type -ksp_gmres_restart'
  petsc_options_value = ' asm      2              lu            gmres     200'
[]



[Outputs]
  file_base = uni_axial1
  exodus = true
  [./csv]
    type = CSV
    [../]
[]

Thank you !

Hello
The initial stress should be saved to your exodus output at every time step.
But are you trying to re-use it inside your simulation, to compute a difference for example?
If you are trying to save and re-use the initial condition, you can use a SelfAux executed on INITIAL to make a copy of the stress_... variables.
If you are trying to save and re-use the first (or any other) time step, you can use a SelfAux AND the Control system to run it on a particular time step
OR
you can use a solutionUserObject or an exodus restart to reload the solution at a given time step from a previous solve.
There might be other options too. Cant think of more right now
Guillaume

node.title: A question about PolycrystalColoringIC
node.bodyText:
Hi, MOOSE team,
I wanted to use the block parameter for the PolycrystalColoringIC in my work and found it was not working.
There was a warning sign saying block was not used.
How can I set the block id for PolycrystalColoringIC? Actually, when I used the PolycrystalVoronoiVoidIC, it worked, and there was no warning.
Is it possible the code did not enable setting block id PolycrystalColoringIC?
Thanks very much,
Kaijie
[ICs]
[./PolycrystalICs]
[./PolycrystalColoringIC] #PolycrystalColoringIC not working?
polycrystal_ic_uo = voronoi
block = '1 2 3'
[../]
[../]
[]

The  PolycrystalColoringIC assigns grains based on the information provided by the polycrystal_ic_uo, that's why it's not using the block information you provided. You will have to specify the blocks in the UserObject for this.

I just tried the following UserObjects, but still, there were warnings about the unused block. It was not working.
[UserObjects]
[./voronoi]
type = PolycrystalVoronoi
grain_num = 10
rand_seed = 12444
block = '1 2 3'
[../]
[./grain_tracker]
type = GrainTracker
threshold = 0.2
connecting_threshold = 0.08
compute_halo_maps = true # Only necessary for displaying HALOS
block = '1 2 3'
[../]
[]
Great! I likely need boundary restriction later. I appreciate it if you could solve both of them.
@GiudGiud you edited the wrong class. See below.

how did I manage that... I edited like 6 of these IC actions.
Ok i ll fix that up
oh I edited that one as well already, i just posted the wrong link
Added boundary restriction, made the PR #19194
We'll need to add the block parameter to the PolycrystalColoringICAction. Should be pretty straight forward!
Thanks so much. PolycrystalColoringICAction was not working instead of PolycrystalVoronoiVoidICAction, as far I know.
Ok with the merging of #19194 this should be fixed. Thanks for reporting this!

Thanks very much.
I updated MOOSE and implemented the following commands. But after compiling my application, it was not working. Is there anything wrong when I did the update?
(moose) [moose@localhost moose]$ **git rebase origin/master**
error: cannot rebase: You have unstaged changes.
error: Please commit or stash them.
(moose) [moose@localhost moose]$ **git rebase origin/master**
error: cannot rebase: You have unstaged changes.
error: Please commit or stash them.
(moose) [moose@localhost moose]$ **git stash**
Saved working directory and index state WIP on master: 59fb6b81d3 Merge commit '579cc6274bfa1525b7962796270dfcdbb1bb27b0'
(base) [moose@localhost moose]$ **git pull --rebase --autostash**
Successfully rebased and updated refs/heads/master.
(base) [moose@localhost moose]$ **git stash pop**
On branch master
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/master'.
Changes not staged for commit:
  (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
  (use "git restore <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
	modified:   modules/phase_field/test/tests/rigidbodymotion/polycrystal_action.i
	modified:   modules/tensor_mechanics/test/tests/global_strain/global_strain_disp.i
Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
	coupled_pressure_test1.i
	examples/a_MyCourse_Final/
	modules/combined/examples/publications/rapid_dev/fig7b-1.i
	modules/combined/examples/publications/rapid_dev/fig8-1.i
no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
Dropped refs/stash@{0} (a16e1507545f4303d6c58d3ed114911cfd84983c)
(base) [moose@localhost moose]$ **git status**
On branch master
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/master'.

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
	coupled_pressure_test1.i
	examples/a_MyCourse_Final/
	modules/combined/examples/publications/rapid_dev/fig7b-1.i
	modules/combined/examples/publications/rapid_dev/fig8-1.i

nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)

did you re-compile?
What you did with git updated the source code, but it did not update the executable

Yes, I recompiled it and passed all the tests. It showed the latest MOOSE version. But I checked the folder and found PolycrystalColoringIC was not updated.
See below the three snapshots.
oh it s because you pulled in the master branch. The changes I merged in arent in master yet. They are still in devel or next.

oh looks like the changes are in master now
https://github.com/idaholab/moose/commits/master
but the one you pulled was literally two commits before my PR got in master. If you repeat the maneuver now it should work
Yes. You were right. I repeated it and it works now. Thanks very much.
